info.game_comments:
2001 College Championship semifinal game 3.
From the campus at UCLA.

(1, 1).clue: They look a little different now; the 1965 cover seen here was headed, this machine "in Society"

(2, 1).clue: "Criminal intent" is NBC's latest spin-off of this series

(3, 1).clue: These ever-popular dogs are known as Scotties for short

(4, 1).clue: Every summer it's time to rev your engines for a race to the top of this famous Colorado peak

(5, 1).clue: This brand calls itself "the champagne of bottled waters"

(6, 1).clue: The leg & thigh of the chicken

(1, 2).clue: In 1968 Time said the Pope's "stern no" to this would make the Church's work harder in overpopulated countries

(2, 2).clue: The agency in CBS's "The Agency" & behind ABC's "Alias"

(3, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from the Page Museum in Los Angeles.)  Creatures from 28,000 years ago who sported the look seen here

(4, 2).clue: It's the highest mountain in Greece & that's no myth!

(5, 2).clue: The logo of this juice brand is seen here

(1, 3).clue: They're the 2 men on the cover here in a hopeful moment in history

(3, 3).clue: The American curl cat is so-named because this pair of features curls back to give it an alert appearance

(4, 3).clue: These mountains extend into 7 countries, including Colombia, Ecuador & Peru

(5, 3).clue: This soft drink has used the slogan "Image is nothing... obey your thirst"

(6, 3).clue: You'll find a developer, a stop bath & a fixer here

(1, 4).clue: 1933 coverage of FDR usually mentioned this ivory accessory between his jaunty lips

(2, 4).clue: Mr. Holland on film, he became Max Bickford on TV

(3, 4).clue: The Clumber breed of this dog was named for Clumber Park, the Duke of Newcastle's estate

(4, 4).clue: Rip Van Winkle took his 20-year snooze in these mountains of New York

(5, 4).clue: It's what the RC stands for in RC Cola

(6, 4).clue: This term referred to a supposed lack of learning in the period from the 400s to the 900s

(1, 5).clue: Governor of the '70s seen here; today, he's a mayor

(2, 5).clue: Rose McGowan is the new Halliwell sister on this WB series

(3, 5).clue: Though this dog is called "Rhodesian", it actually hails from South Africa

(4, 5).clue: Check your map book: these mountains extend more than 1,200 miles across Morocco, Algeria & Tunisia

(5, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew sips coffee with Jimmy in New Orleans.)  The delicious cafe au lait at the cafe du monde is flavored with this plant; it's related to endive

(6, 5).clue: It's postulated this hypothetical substance accounts for gravitational forces observed in the universe

(1, 1).clue: You'll find his office at the Palacio de la Revolution in Havana

(2, 1).clue: Gary's mother had 3 children, one named April, one named June & one named this

(3, 1).clue: This word, used to describe a crowd in a Thomas Hardy title, means "frenzied"

(4, 1).clue: Jackie Chan & Chris Tucker teamed up again in the sequel to this 1998 action comedy

(5, 1).clue: A gascon was a braggart, after the supposedly boastful people of Gascony in this country

(6, 1).clue: Francisco Pizarro was killed by a competing conquistador after looting & destroying this Peruvian empire

(1, 2).clue: This French emperor's return to power in 1815 lasted about one hundred days

(2, 2).clue: Just before Mount Everest was discovered, this was the highest mountain in the world

(3, 2).clue: Barrie, Housman, Shaw & Kipling were pallbearers at Hardy's funeral at this church; his ashes lie in Poets' Corner

(4, 2).clue: John Leguizamo played Toulouse-Lautrec in this 2001 movie musical

(5, 2).clue: A dotard was someone whose intelligence & faculties were faulty for this reason

(6, 2).clue: Pedro Menendez de Aviles founded this Florida city on his way to massacring a rival colony

(1, 3).clue: 1 of 2 Yitzhaks since the '70s to serve as prime minister of Israel

(2, 3).clue: Of Boris Karloff, Lon Chaney or Colin Clive, the one who played the title role in the 1931 film "Frankenstein"

(3, 3).clue: This 1891 Hardy novel is subtitled "A Pure Woman"

(4, 3).clue: Charlton Heston had a cameo in this 2001 remake directed by Tim Burton

(5, 3).clue: 3-letter word for a mongrel dog or an unsavory person

(6, 3).clue: Burke & Wills were the first to cross this continent south to north; they died on the way back

(1, 4).clue: In February 2001 Jean-Bertrand Aristide returned to power as president of this country

(2, 4).clue: The act of seeing is actually performed by this organ, not the eye

(3, 4).clue: Michael Henchard becomes this town official, the title of an 1886 Hardy novel

(4, 4).clue: Vin Diesel can't drive 55 in this 2001 film that explored the underground world of L.A. street racing

(5, 4).clue: The name of this seabird, meaning "one easily fooled", later had -ible added to it

(6, 4).clue: Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo died from complications of a broken leg on San Miguel Island off this state he explored

(1, 5).clue: In 1910 this European country's last king, Manuel II, was overthrown in a naval revolt

(2, 5).clue: It's the 11-letter word all Canadians pronounce incorrectly

(3, 5).clue: Hardy set many of his novels in this imaginary county in southwestern England

(4, 5).clue: Marcia Gay Harden won an Oscar for playing artist Lee Krasner, this painter's wife, in a 2000 film

(5, 5).clue: "Rascal" evolved into this longer word that sounds like one who strikes green onions

(6, 5).clue: The first European to travel the Mississippi: later his men killed him while trying to find the river in Texas

(0, 0).clue: Tiger Woods' 22-page booklet "The Making of a Champion" came free on one million boxes of this product
